awd_titl_txt: Prediction of Organic-Vapor Wall Deposition Using a Qualitative Structure Activity Relationship and its Application to the Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Environmental chambers are frequently used to investigate atmospheric chemistry in a controlled setting.  This research is focused on developing a model to predict the interactions of gases and particles with the walls of an environmental chamber, and to predict what effects these interactions might have on the results of a study.  For example, the wall effects in an environmental chamber often result in the underestimation of the formation of small particles in the chamber, an error that can be carried through to air-quality and climate models. This project is expected to ultimately improve the predictive capability for the formation of SOA in the atmosphere and improve the estimates of both the direct and indirect effects of SOA on human health and climate. 

The three objectives of the proposal are to: (1) Predict the gas-wall process partitioning constant of various semivolatile organic compounds (SVOCs) and their deposition rate constants using a Quantitative Structure Activity Relation (QSAR) approach; (2) Integrate the gas-wall process model parameters with the model that predicts secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation; and (3) Evaluate the potential for SOA formation produced via multiphase reactions of various hydrocarbons using the amended model including the bias due to the gas-wall process. A model that uses an explicit gas mechanism to predict SOA formation from multiphase reactions, will be amended and applied to investigate the impact of gas-wall processes on the formation of SOA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: Prediction of Organic-Vapor Wall Deposition using a Qualitative Structure Activity Relationship and its Application to the SOA Model

Project NSF number: AGS1923651

PI Name: Myoseon Jang, Department of Environmental Engineering Sciences, University of Florida

Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA), which forms via atmospheric processes of hydrocarbons, represents a significant fraction of fine particulate matter (PM2.5, particle diameter< 2.5?m) ranging from 20-90% of total particulate organic carbons. Therefore, the prediction of SOA is essential for a variety of reasons, including implications on climate forcing, cloud chemistry, visibility, and health.  Despite the significant contribution of SOA to PM2.5, ambient simulations on the regional scale exhibit a persistent low-bias compared to measured organic aerosol (OA). SOA formation is typically estimated based on the condensable organics on suspended particulate mass because particle mass can be simply quantifiable using filter collection or estimated from aerosol size distribution data.  When forming SOA in a reactor, Teflon films are the most commonly used vapor barrier because Teflon films are chemically inert and has the low permeability for chemical species. However, chamber studies are affected by the gas-wall process (GWP) of chemical species due to the difference in chemical potentials of chemical species in the gas phase and on the Teflon film wall. The deposition of organic vapor on walls is a significant fact that potentially would lead to substantial underestimation of SOA formation in laboratories. Consequently, the effect of the chamber wall on SOA models, which are used for the simulation of air quality in regional scales, can be significant increasing uncertainties in prediction.  The ultimate goal of this product was to develop a model for predicting the GWP of various organic vapors using the Quantitative Structure Activity Relation (QSAR) approach that utilizes the molecular structure of organic products originating from the atmospheric process of hydrocarbons. To achieve this goal, we proposed three specific objectives as follows.

Objective 1: Predict the GWP partitioning constant of various organic vapors and their deposition rate constants to chamber walls using a QSAR approach. 

Objective 2: Integrate the GWP model parameters with the SOA model parameters to improve the prediction of SOA formation.

Objective 3: Evaluate the amended SOA model for GWP bias to better predict SOA formation via multiphase reactions of various hydrocarbons

The resulting GWP model vastly improved our ability to predict SOA formation generated from the atmospheric oxidation of hydrocarbons by upgrading SOA model parameters without GWP bias.  The outcomes of this study are as follows.

  • The organic vapor deposition to the chamber wall has been predicted by estimating GWP partitioning constant of various organic structures and their deposition rate constants using a QSAR approach. 
  • The resulting GWP model was able to improve the calculation of the model parameters employed in the UNIfied Partitioning Aerosol Reaction (UNIPAR) model that predicts SOA formation via multiphase reactions of hydrocarbons.
  • The UNIPAR model with amended parameters for GWP bias innovated the prediction of SOA formation generated from atmospheric processed of various hydrocarbons including aromatics (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, propylbenzene, three xylenes, and three trimethylbenzenes); biogenics (terpenes, isoprene, and sesquiterpene) during daytime and nighttime; alkanes in different carbon lengths and branching positions. The performance of the UNIPAR predictability has been demonstrated with SOA data generated in the large outdoor photochemical smog reactor (UF-APHOR chamber)
  • The gasoline SOA formation, which produced from the photooxidation of complex gasoline fuel under varying atmospheric conditions in the outdoor chamber, was simulated using the UNIPAR model integrated into the conventional ozone model to increase the feasibility of the SOA model.
  • Ultimately, the UNIPAR model was incorporated with the Comprehensive Air Quality Model with Extensions (CAMx) to predict the ambient concentration of organic matter (OM) in urban atmospheres and demonstrated using field data obtained during the Korean-United States Air Quality (2016 KORUS-AQ) campaign and field data collected in California, USA (2018).

 


Last Modified: 08/17/2023
Modified by: Myoseon Jang

Images (1 of )

por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Title: Prediction of Organic-Vapor Wall Deposition using a Qualitative Structure Activity Relationship and its Application to the SOA Model
Project NSF number: AGS1923651

PI Name: Myoseon Jang, Department of Environmental Engineering Sciences, University of Florida

Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA), which forms via atmospheric processes of hydrocarbons, represents a significant fraction of fine particulate matter (PM2.5, particle diameter< 2.5?m) ranging from 20-90% of total particulate organic carbons. Therefore, the prediction of SOA is essential for a variety of reasons, including implications on climate forcing, cloud chemistry, visibility, and health.  Despite the significant contribution of SOA to PM2.5, ambient simulations on the regional scale exhibit a persistent low-bias compared to measured organic aerosol (OA). SOA formation is typically estimated based on the condensable organics on suspended particulate mass because particle mass can be simply quantifiable using filter collection or estimated from aerosol size distribution data.  When forming SOA in a reactor, Teflon films are the most commonly used vapor barrier because Teflon films are chemically inert and has the low permeability for chemical species. However, chamber studies are affected by the gas-wall process (GWP) of chemical species due to the difference in chemical potentials of chemical species in the gas phase and on the Teflon film wall. The deposition of organic vapor on walls is a significant fact that potentially would lead to substantial underestimation of SOA formation in laboratories. Consequently, the effect of the chamber wall on SOA models, which are used for the simulation of air quality in regional scales, can be significant increasing uncertainties in prediction.  The ultimate goal of this product was to develop a model for predicting the GWP of various organic vapors using the Quantitative Structure Activity Relation (QSAR) approach that utilizes the molecular structure of organic products originating from the atmospheric process of hydrocarbons. To achieve this goal, we proposed three specific objectives as follows.

Objective 1: Predict the GWP partitioning constant of various organic vapors and their deposition rate constants to chamber walls using a QSAR approach. 

Objective 2: Integrate the GWP model parameters with the SOA model parameters to improve the prediction of SOA formation.

Objective 3: Evaluate the amended SOA model for GWP bias to better predict SOA formation via multiphase reactions of various hydrocarbons 

The resulting GWP model vastly improved our ability to predict SOA formation generated from the atmospheric oxidation of hydrocarbons by upgrading SOA model parameters without GWP bias.  The outcomes of this study are as follows. 

The organic vapor deposition to the chamber wall has been predicted by estimating GWP partitioning constant of various organic structures and their deposition rate constants using a QSAR approach.  
The resulting GWP model was able to improve the calculation of the model parameters employed in the UNIfied Partitioning Aerosol Reaction (UNIPAR) model that predicts SOA formation via multiphase reactions of hydrocarbons. 
The UNIPAR model with amended parameters for GWP bias innovated the prediction of SOA formation generated from atmospheric processed of various hydrocarbons including aromatics (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, propylbenzene, three xylenes, and three trimethylbenzenes); biogenics (terpenes, isoprene, and sesquiterpene) during daytime and nighttime; alkanes in different carbon lengths and branching positions. The performance of the UNIPAR predictability has been demonstrated with SOA data generated in the large outdoor photochemical smog reactor (UF-APHOR chamber)
The gasoline SOA formation, which produced from the photooxidation of complex gasoline fuel under varying atmospheric conditions in the outdoor chamber, was simulated using the UNIPAR model integrated into the conventional ozone model to increase the feasibility of the SOA model. 
Ultimately, the UNIPAR model was incorporated with the Comprehensive Air Quality Model with Extensions (CAMx) to predict the ambient concentration of organic matter (OM) in urban atmospheres and demonstrated using field data obtained during the Korean-United States Air Quality (2016 KORUS-AQ) campaign and field data collected in California, USA (2018). 


 

					Last Modified: 08/17/2023

					Submitted by: Myoseon Jang
